summary.seg: This manuscript, which is datable to the late 16th century, contains Demosthenes' oration De falsa legatione; the text is incomplete and accompanied by a marginal Latin commentary. Since a few passages of the commentary are in English, it can be assumed that it was the work of an English scholar.

At the beginning of the manuscript, there is a series of epigrams and brief verses in Greek, Latin, and French by various scholars and intellectuals of the 16th century, mostly from the Genevan Calvinist circle: the Greek-Italian classical scholar Franciscus Portus (1511-1581), his son Aemilius, the French printer Henri II Estienne (1531-1598), the French theologian Theodore Beza (1519-1605) and others. Various of these compositions were written in commemoration of John Calvin (1509-1564).

msItem.title: Collection of epigrams and other fragments in Greek, Latin and French, including texts on the death of John Calvin, by Franciscus Portus, Aemilius Portus, Theodore Beza, Henri Estienne and others
msItem.author: Franciscus Portus
Theodore Beza
Henri Estienne
Aemilius Portus

f. [i] recto ll. 19-23 Responsio Francisci Porti ad Theodorum Bezam, inc. Τρισμάκαρ ὦ τετράκις τ' Ἀνακρείων ὀππότε Βέζαι

f. [iv] verso ll. 36-41, Francois du Latin (Quale iubar) et du Grec (ὡς δ' ὅτε) J. C., inc. Αinsi que la lueur de la lampe. At the end: τῶ ἀπὸ τοῦ Χριστοῦ ͵αφξδ΄ ἔθανεν Ιωάννης ὁ Καλβῖνος

msItem.author: Demosthenes
msItem.title: De falsa legatione
msItem.rubric: f. 3r Δεμοσθενους ο περὶ τῆς παραπρεσβείας λόγος
msItem.incipit: f. 3r Οση μέν, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, σπουδὴ περὶ τουτονὶ τὸν ἀγῶνα
msItem.explicit: f. 94r ὥστε μηδενὶ νῦν ὑμῶν εὐσεβῶς
msItem.note: The text ends imperfectly at C. Fuhr (ed.), Demosthenis orationes, I, Leipzig 1914, p. 481 l. 5 (407.212)
The text is written only on the recto of the leaves; it is accompanied by a lexical, grammatical, rhetorical commentary in Latin, written in the margins
There is a lacuna between ff. 6r and 8r, due to the loss of f. 7: καὶ μεγάλων καιρὸν ἐν βραχεῖ προσετάξατε ἐν τῇ πρεσβείᾳ πεποιηκότα ( Fuhr 1914, p. 405 ll. 6-19 [343.6-8])

support.material:
ff. [i]-91v Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermarks: ff. [i]-[vi], 87-94 Coat of arms with a dog/fox, surmounted by a quatrefoil, under it letters W I
( ca. 55 ca. 30 ) in the gutter, very similar to Piccard online, Wappen DE4620-PO-85887 which is dated to 1562 (Germany).
ff. 3-32 Hand surmounted by a five-point star ( ca. 72 ca. 35 ) in the gutter, comparable to Briquet, Main 11357 which is dated to 1557.
ff. 33-86 Pitcher, on it letters I/L (?) C (with clover) B, surmounted by a four-leaf clover
( ca. 55 ca. 25 ) in the gutter, comparable to Briquet Pot 12742 which is dated in the years 1550-1585.

supportDesc.foliation: The leaves are foliated 3-94 in Arabic numerals, in the top right hand corner recto. From f. 60, where the original foliation is not visible anymore due to leaves' trimming, it is partially supplemented by a foliation in modern pencil; ff. [i]-[vi] have not been numbered; ff. 1, 2 and 7 are lost. The foliation is: [i]-[vi] + 3-6, 8-94.

collation.p: The first two quires are binions, the second lost the last two leaves without loss of text. The third is a quaternion which has lost the first two leaves (without loss of text) and the 7th (f. 7, with loss of text). Quaternions follow.

list.item: Quire 14 ff. [i]-[iv]
Quire 24-2 ff. [v]-[vi](3rd, 4th leaves missing)
Quire 38-3 ff. 3-6, 8(1st, 2nd, 7th leaves missing)
Quires 4-7 8 ff. 9-40
Quire 8 6 ff. 41-46
Quires 9-14 8 ff. 47-94

collation.catchwords: Horizontal catchwords by the scribe on the lower part, right, of the verso of each leaf, until f. 76v.

supportDesc.condition: The codex is in fair condition. The binding is damaged. On the leaves, near the gutter, there are humidity and water stains, and tears. In the manuscript there are three loose inserts made of modern paper and remnant of thread housed in a pocket. The last three quires are detached from the book block.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. [i] recto-[vi] recto Irregular layout, 1-2 columns, 29 to 44 lines.
ca. 170 ca. 130
ff. 3r-94r A single column of 16 to 25 lines. On ff. 3r-81r the scribe traced a frame in red ink delimiting the space for the text and for the commentary. ca. 130 ca. 75

handNote.p: ff. ff. [i] recto-[vi] recto, 3r-94r Hand A: most part of Demosthenes' text has been written in a minuscule script, probably by a western European hand, as the rigid ductus, and some forms, similar to the Latin alphabet, indicate. From f. 82r the script becomes more rapid, and slants slightly to the right.
The text is written in brown ink; the first line of the text on each folio in red, is now faded.

binding.p: Early modern limp parchment binding. There are four alum-tawed ties to each board. An envelope is adhered to the inside of the right cover, added presumably to house the loose-leaf insertions (see Accompanying material). On the spine, on the upper part there is a title, Demosthenes de falsa legatione, on the lower part the shelfmark Add. 6314.
binding.condition: The cover has been damaged by pest, the corners of the textblock have been revealed in some places. Three loose inserts made of modern paper and remnant of thread at the beginning of the textblock have been housed in a pocket. Offset remains on the inside of the left cover, from a former pastedown comprising a leaf recycled from a medieval manuscript (no longer present in this manuscript).

accMat.p: In the manuscript, in a plastic pocket, are kept three small paper leaves, with information about the book.

On one of them ( 178 126 ), the name of one of the owners of the manuscript, Neville Holt, is written twice in pencil. There is also a note in black ink, probably by a librarian: Demosthenes de falsa legatione. The Greek text with a copious Latin commentary, written by an English scholar in the time of Queen Elizabeth. M.S. on paper (Add. 6314).

On another ( 79 159 ) there is a note written by the former owner Neville Holt to ask for a valuation of two books, probably one of them being this manuscript: Would you be kind enough to let me know what the value | of the two enclosed books would be. I am wanted to | sell them to a man and do not know what price | to ask, being ignorant of their value. | F. Neville Holt. Under this note, the same hand which wrote the name of Neville Holt in pencil on the aformentioned leaf wrote in pencil: Rockingham House Newmarket Aug. 1921. On the opposite side of this leaf, written transversally, there are some annotations in black ink and in pencil written by the same librarian's hand found in the aforementioned leaf, listing some passages written in English in the manuscript, in the commentary accompanying Demosthenes' text.

The last leaf ( 203 128 ) contains annotations in ink by another modern hand, concerning the texts written in the manuscript on ff. [i]-[vi]. On the leaf there is a stamp of Cambridge University Library with the date of 1921.

origin.p: On the basis of the watermarks, the manuscript can be dated to the second half of the 16th century.

provenance.p:
The codex was owned by the librarian F. Neville Holt F. Neville Holt
( Easterling (1962), p. 321).

history.acquisition:
In 1921, the Cambridge University Librarian F.J.H. Jenkinson F.J.H. Jenkinson
acquired the manuscript from Neville Holt and presented it, in the same year, to the Library. The date is present on three stamps of CUL on ff. [i] recto and 94r.

recordHist.source: Description (2020) draws partly on P. Easterling, 'Hand-list of the additional Greek manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge', Scriptorium 16 (1962), 302-323 (p. 321), and on an umpublished description by the librarian R.V. Kerr, kept at Cambridge University Library.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

analytic.title: Hand-list of the additional Greek manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge
